title: Remove 'No data yet' text under Weekly/Monthly measurements on Dashboard header

requirements.text: Update the Dashboard header measurements section so that when there is no Weekly measurements data, the UI does not render the fallback text "No data yet" under the "Weekly" label.

quotes: remove below nuvio weekly non data yet monthly no data yet

acceptanceCriteria: When weekly measurements contain no values > 0, the Dashboard header does not display the text "No data yet" anywhere under the "Weekly" label.
The "Weekly" label itself remains visible (unless it is intentionally hidden by REQ-3).

requirements.text: Update the Dashboard header measurements section so that when there is no Monthly measurements data, the UI does not render the fallback text "No data yet" under the "Monthly" label.

quotes: remove below nuvio weekly non data yet monthly no data yet

acceptanceCriteria: When monthly measurements contain no values > 0, the Dashboard header does not display the text "No data yet" anywhere under the "Monthly" label.
The "Monthly" label itself remains visible (unless it is intentionally hidden by REQ-3).

requirements.text: If both Weekly and Monthly measurements have no data, ensure the header measurements row does not leave an empty placeholder gap on the Dashboard (i.e., it should collapse to minimal/zero height).

quotes: remove below nuvio weekly non data yet monthly no data yet

acceptanceCriteria: With no weekly data and no monthly data, the Dashboard does not show empty measurement containers/spacers below the header row, and the next section starts immediately after the header block with normal spacing.

constraints: Do not modify files under frontend/src/components/ui (read-only).
Do not modify immutable hook bootstrap/auth files (frontend/src/hooks/useInternetIdentity.ts, frontend/src/hooks/useActor.ts, frontend/src/main.tsx).
nonGoals: Do not change how measurements are edited/saved (MeasurementsEditorDialog behavior remains the same).
Do not change measurement data models or persistence.
